content.description: Start 2-3 feet right of the tree ( facing project boulder).  Climb up the slab shooting for pockets on the left side up under the mini roof, skeet left to get over the roof then head up a little right again to top it out.
content.protection: multiple pads.  Gets the R rating because if you fall you will most definitely hit the tree on your way down.

content.description:
Starts in the middle of project boulder and climbs up towards the center using a right hand rail to get to a left hand crimp positioned in the center of the wall before the overhang starts. From here start to move right reaching up to a small left hand two finger side pull.  Throw right up and over the roof to find a juicy rail.  One more move to a deep pocket and walk your feet up over the roof and continue climbing a slabby section for another 6 feet to top.   

  Barbed Wire boulder is off as well as chossy looking stuff on right before over hang.

Start on the left side of the main face of Project Boulder. Use similar beginning holds as Welcome to Gumby Town. Go right along the pockets on the left side of the roof. Use the thin rail and shallow pockets to stick the jug at the prow. Don't blow the topout!
content.protection: There are a couple large rocks near the back of the landing zone. 3-4 Pads plus 2 spotters is ideal if you don't want an oardeal while you're working the last couple moves.
content.location: Left direct line on the roof of the Project Boulder.

content.description:
Starts matched on the chest-high horizontal pocket on the left of the bulge. Throw left and up for some smaller crimpy pockets before tossing big into the moss on the face of the slab. Head straight up, avoid the holds out right and leaving the moss (c'mon, you're barely 15ft up!) Good jugs and pinches to be had up into the roof, so calm down and forget you're standing in moss. Get some high feet and go for the bomber baseball-sized jug on top just left of the prow, (about 6 inches farther than you want it.) Take a deep breath and mantle the thing. Don't forget to look down and notice you are pretty stinkin' high for a boulder problem. 

  Named for the fact that the boulder itself looks like a human heart AND that the moss on the left of the slab face looks like a half of a heart symbol.
content.protection: 2 pads and 2 spotters preferable.The landing zone has a pointed rock that does a good job as a backstop for the second. Don't commit to the mantle topout if you don't have well trained spottersâ€“ traverse right onto easier holds and up through the gunsight instead.
content.location: Climbs the straightest route directly up the slab face through the moss. Starts 4ft to the left of the R-rated tree from Gumbytown. Walkoff is the recently cleaned class 4 scramble to the right past the large cedar when you topout.

content.description: Feels natural, but definitely also a little contrived. That's what bouldering is all about! Start by stepping on the slab and going up left hand to a good pocket. Your hands should always stay on the more blank vertical face until you near the top. The picture will make it more understandable.
Tall, slightly overhanging boulder with few holds.  This boulder holds two of the best looking lines in the park and they have yet to see a first ascent.
